I had very high hopes for this class-- this class came highly recommended by 2nd year students even during my admitted student orientation (some calling it their favorite class at YSPH) -- and for me, it totally fell flat. I learned an INCREDIBLE amount of information about how the US healthcare system is set up and some of the challenges with health policy - so I find that a win, however I had a hard time feeling engaged throughout the semester.  I understand the importance of making this course a required class but the large lecture hall and recordings (which I think led to a decline in student attendance) left me feeling like the course lacked depth. I often felt disconnected with course material, as there was not really an opportunity for sharing of ideas and more fruitful discussion of view points.

I cannot say enough positive things about this class. This was truly one of the best courses I've ever taken. The material was useful, engaging, and interesting. I think one of the best features of the class is the "in the news" segment. This really helped to tie together what we were learning in class with what is happening in the real world. This was an excellent opportunity to move beyond the classroom. 

Additionally, the exams and assignments were extremely fair, interesting, and transparent in the expectations. 


In my view, this class has no weaknesses, though I would recommend moving the policy workshops to a larger room. I also didn't like having to go to Alexion (not a comfortable room for a lecture), but there's nothing that can be done about that.

This course is brilliant; one of the best I've taken in my academic career. It's incredibly well taught, the syllabus and expectations are clearly outlined, and the material is compelling. Zero criticism/no areas of weakness to comment on.

Additional (specific) strengths:
-Conscientiousness on the part of the professor so exams and writing assignments were not scheduled on the same week as exams in other required courses for 1st year MPH students
-Clear and specific instructions for all assignments, including the final (this was particularly helpful for the final as theoretical paper-based exams can be tough to study for)
-Consistently interesting and engaging readings
-Manageable course load in terms of volume for the semester (especially compared to other required courses)
-Logical structure in terms of syllabus with assignments spaced out in a reasonable manner
Jason is a wonderful instructor. Goes above and beyond for his students, and creates opportunities for supplemental learning.

I have nothing but great things to say about this course. This was by far my favorite course this semester and I was thrilled to have learned so much about health policy. This course presented very useful material and Jason was a wonderful lecturer. Truly marvelous and well-designed! The main weaknesses in my opinion is the difficulty in understanding the grading system.

This class was a true joy to take. Everyone loves Jason Schwartz, but also the subject matter is the perfect level of in-depth for the course. 
Strengths:
-Professor interesting to listen to and course interesting. Medicare week was the best week of my semester. In my opinion, pretty much the only class that wasn't completely awful to have in a 200 person lecture setting (though even this one would be WAY better if it was <70 people. 
- Seems like the right level of work on a weekly basis, readings are really interesting for the most part. 
-I like the news part, gives me greater context around the things I read every day.
-I will out myself as a policy student in case it wasn't already obvious :). I think the sessions we have with just policy students alleviated my feelings that this class wasn't in depth enough for us in the beginning. Also they were all great!!!

Weaknesses:
-I really really wish one of the written assignments was more substantial or at least a policy memo. I have 3 different scholarship/internship applications due early next semester that require 5-10 page writing samples and I literally haven't written anything this semester longer than 800 words! This seems like the best course to add a longer paper too, and it does feel a little too "easy" to have all of the writing assignments be shorter than the prompts themselves :). Also I LOVED writing both essays, and learned more about health policy doing the research for each than I did in some other classes for the whole semester. I learn best through having to make an argument and researching, so it would be better to have an outlet for that. 
- The exams were kinda fun to study for, but there is essentially no incentive to come to class or do the readings (most students who got honors on the first exam seemed to have better luck joining a reading "cliff notes" pool, so probably did 2-3 readings max). I did all of the readings AND went to every class AND am a policy student AND actually know a lot about this class, but I didn't get an honors on the first exam. it was kind of hard to remember the "bulletpoints" on the slide for things like "trade off" when people who actually work in policy have a functioning knowledge of that word. The exams seemed to be graded in a way that reward memorization of slides alone.
I loved this course! I've lived in the US my whole life but never understood the healthcare system until I took this course. Loved every lecture and always looked forward to class.

AP- 
Excellent overview of key concepts in health policy. Prof Schwartz really understands how to create an arc in the course, building upon key concepts.
As a medical student with little understanding of health policy, the course really hit on key concepts that allowed me to engage in many different HP topics.

Assessments were VERY leniently graded with bonuses, with exam averages at 90%/94% respectively, and ~60-70% Honors on the two essays.

Loved the fairness of exam assessments and the detailed manner in which exams were returned in sealed manila envelopes... while I did reuse these envelopes multiple times and this method of exam distribution seemed highly efficient, I wonder about the sustainability of this endeavor, in addition to the printing out of hundreds of assignment sheets. Very appreciative of the attention to detail and organization required but wondering if there were a more eco-friendly option in such a large course.

Awesome course!  I've never learned so much in a class as I have in this one.  The recordings of the lectures were incredibly helpful to retain information and clarify notes!  I think it would've been helpful to read a required book for the class, realizing that there isn't one perfect non-textbook that could encompass all of American health policy.  But I think understanding more about 1 perspective on the health system would be useful.  I think there were a lot of articles, which were interesting and well-chosen, but a book may provide deeper insight.  
The midterms could've had more specific feedback on the points taken off.  
Also, felt the rubric for writing assignments was a little unclear.

No offense to the instructor and TAs. They are good at teaching. But I don't think this course should be a requirement to all MPH students. I am an international student majoring Biostatistics. The topic of the course is of absolutely NO interest to me, and since I'm not from the U.S., it is extremely hard for me to understand the U.S. health system and explain it in a professional way. Since all exams are close-booked, I had to spend a lot of time remembering over 1000 slides and I don't find it helpful to be forced to memorize the knowledge with no way to understand. From a Biostat student's point of view, the time should be wisely used to learn statistical knowledge which will benefit the students' future career more. This class is a complete waste of time for biostat students. It is not helpful since not all MPH students want to work in the policy field in the future. The knowledge is good to know but students should not be assigned to it. It is meaningless especially for international students since they don't come from the same health system. It is ridiculous that no matter what background you are from, and what major you are in, you are REQUIRED to take a policy class just to get the degree. As a graduate student, we should have the freedom to choose courses and design our own curriculum. I highly suggest to make this course optional to MPH students! For example, MPH students can choose 4 out of 6  core courses to study and this health policy course can be on the list, but it's optional for students to choose as a core course. Students like me just memorize over 1000 slides to pass the exam. It's unfair for international students who have never exposed to the U.S health system and who are not even interested in the policy filed to learn this course. The only point of this course for students like me is to lower the GPA.

I genuinely enjoyed attending every lecture of this course. The readings for this course were well chosen in terms of varying lengths, perspectives, and quality which I very much appreciated. However, I did feel less prepared for the first writing assignment than the second writing assignment based on the material covered in lectures before both. But in general, I felt well supported and resourced just with the materials provided by the professor; I only attended group TF reviews and even then, office hours with the professor still felt more useful to me.

I also loved the parts of the class where we went over health news! The writing assignments were also really fun.
This is an excellent course. The format and materials were very strong!
